results.content:
The subject matter (Svelte) was pertinent to me because our company is header down the path of Angular (UGH!). Svelte is a simpler technology that I wouldn't have looked at without a course such as this. 
What I like about the format of this course is the author intermingled sections where the code for the section was an independent exercise and the following section picked up on the course project. This is definitely one of my favorite courses...and authors.

I'd love to see more courses from Max regarding the use of Svelte. For example, Svelte with Bootstrap. Also a small course on how to implement some advanced features with Svelte and HTML5 such as Drag and drop.  This course, like Svelte is awesome!

Great course from a fabulous teacher. I would recommend Max as a tutor and the topic coverage was great. 

Some lectures I had to watch a couple of times for newer svelte specific topics or handling to sink in, but Max does a good job explaining things well. results.content: Swelte is a great framework. Max is a great instructor but on this one, I  find that the rhythm was a bit off and difficult to follow sometimes ( sometimes too quick and you don't have time to check the syntax, and other times it's too long). Examples are often mixed up and built on top of each others which is not the best option to explain something IMHO. Configuration files for the project are not working correctly and it's really annoying having to spend 2h to figure out how to properly configure the provided project-setup file (package.json, rollup.js etc.) Of course configuration and bundlers are not the main purpose of this course but the least to be done would be to update the config files as long as you're selling this training. Sapper is not maintained nor developed anymore, SvelteKit is live since 21 march 2021 and deserves a big update of this training cause the subject is dense.

results.content:
In terms of the rate of learning, this is a great course for bringing n00bs like me up to speed.

HOWEVER, the course materials (code samples that you use as a base in each lesson, etc) contain loads of outdated code. As a n00b, you're left wondering whether you messed something up, or whether it's another bug in the sample code. You end up spending as much time looking up fixes for the attachments from the teacher, as you do actually watching the lectures, which makes the motivation to "keep coming back for more" all that harder.

If the course materials got a (much needed) refresh, this would be a 5 star course.

results.content:
Very good, understandable and quick overview, for quickly diving into svelte.js. It also at least touches some of the concepts possible, like using svelte for widgets with other templating engines.
I personally also find the example appealing and useful to display and explain the concepts used in svelte.
If I would need to criticize something: Sometimes there is a lot of jumping either in between a single file or different files, which made it a bit difficult to follow. Partly this is because of how an application is build, and partly it may be because I played it at increased speed ;-).
One thing that disturbed me, though: In some videos, some libraries are mentioned. But there is no trace of them, neither in the description nor in the chapter summaries nor in the "Further material"-section.
All in all a good course for diving into svelte.js quickly.

results.content: I really enjoyed the course and completed it feeling I could start writing Svelte apps.  In addition to covering the a good deal of the Svelte topics, I also appreciate the topics on deployment techniques.  I like his practice of including his CSS as a download with some lessons.  I need to improve my CSS, so I enjoyed studying them and adding them piece-by-piece to see what changed, even though that wasn't the focus of the course.  My only complaint was that some of the starting-point downloads wouldn't build.  At first, I took it as an opportunity to become better acquainted with rollup and its plugins.  That did help.  But after a few times, it got to be bothersome.  Perhaps a note to the students that, since Svelte and its ecosystem are so new, a word or two on rollup plugin dependencies are in order.

results.content:
Maximilian is an excellent teacher, as usual. The course structure is ideal for a good understanding: a module on theory followed by a module on practice. We are building with Maximilian an interesting project, step by step.
While all of Svelte's core features are explained with clarity and precision, the Sapper module is a bit overflown and lacks detail. But this is not a Sapper course.
The speech comparing Svelte to React / Vue / Angular is very interesting and constitutes an excellent conclusion.

results.content:
I am looking for a framework to assist with prototyping apps, and I think Svelte is potentially a good fit. I was surprised how quickly Max got things on the page doing complex things very quickly. The only negative on svelte seems to be around the tooling and VSCode integration - this is still buggy/lacking in areas. (Even Max got frustrated at times with the tools at times.)

Max does a good job of explaining the core concepts and how to implement and build a Svelte app

The only negative is there isn't a section on how to Test the components. A module on that would be helpful as well, but I suspect it's not that easy yet with Svelte (based on the little on I could find around it on the official docs)

I audited the completed course. Got a very good overall understanding of how Svelte works. Very excited to try this out in my next side project. Two observations for now -

results.content:
I didn't like the pace of the course. Max tends to show you an incorrect way of doing things first and showing you how to properly do it later in the same video, and this honestly is a horrible experience, because he doesn't tell you up-front he is going to do that. The amount of content is good. The course covered most of what you need to know to build your own apps. It did, however, still lack some things like testing. Some of the code in this course is very "hacky" in my opinion. Especially the part where we try to sync the data from Firebase with the stores just didn't feel right. The course project also didn't cover some features that would've made it more interesting, such as pagination or searching. The project also feels poorly designed since there is no user authentication so every user has the same "favorite" meetups.

All in all I learned quite a bit about how to use Svelte from this course. If you have _a lot_ of patience with the pacing, then this course might be worth it, but I can't really recommend it and I'm just glad to be done with it. I feel like Max's other courses that I've taken were better, but I took those way earlier in my coding career.

response.content: Hi! I sometimes get this "he should show the final approach directly" feedback and I'll never agree with it. My goal is to teach you WHY we do something the way we do it. And to show you alternatives. That involves getting there step by step instead of just throwing the solution at you. You don't learn much from that in my opinion. I'm sorry to hear my teaching style didn't connect with you.

results.content_html:
I didn't like the pace of the course. Max tends to show you an incorrect way of doing things first and showing you how to properly do it later in the same video, and this honestly is a horrible experience, because he doesn't tell you up-front he is going to do that. The amount of content is good. The course covered most of what you need to know to build your own apps. It did, however, still lack some things like testing. Some of the code in this course is very "hacky" in my opinion. Especially the part where we try to sync the data from Firebase with the stores just didn't feel right. The course project also didn't cover some features that would've made it more interesting, such as pagination or searching. The project also feels poorly designed since there is no user authentication so every user has the same "favorite" meetups.

All in all I learned quite a bit about how to use Svelte from this course. If you have _a lot_ of patience with the pacing, then this course might be worth it, but I can't really recommend it and I'm just glad to be done with it. I feel like Max's other courses that I've taken were better, but I took those way earlier in my coding career.

results.content:
1. Svelte is amazing.
2. Max is my favourite instructor.

I highly recommend this course.  My knowledge of JS okay, I understand the syntax and I can solve simple problems.  I have very limited practical experience with JS, however, and this is proving to be challenging as I work my way through the course.  That said, I am able to grind my way through everything and I think if I had a stronger grasp of programming and/or JS in general I would probably find this course very simple.  As it is, I'm finding it manageable but extremely difficult.

results.content:
Well the course is great and worth to be learned.  I can compare to Angular it has many similarities, and I even think that missing some features in Svelte is not a big problem, for example http client and validation. I even like using fetch or validate.js. Syntax is really easy to be grasped. 

Sapper is a bit confusing, i mean the deployment part of it, personally i did not get it as well as rest course content. i will rate course with 4.5 because last sections were like on 2X forward. Some how it was not clear enough, it just my personal experience it may be different for you.

Max is great teacher, thanks him a lot.

results.content:
Yet another great course from Max which I can recommend without any caveats.
It is well-paced and covers pretty much anything necessary to understand Svelte and Sapper and the concepts behind them. 
On top of that, it has a couple of useful exercises thrown in where it makes sense, which helps to solidify the learned theoretical concepts in memory via practical application.

results.content:
Maximilian never fails to bring the best courses in this platform. The way this course was set is awesome - a new clean instance of a project in each new section to learn the concepts, and only then applying it to the main project. It's a very nice way to learn "theory"and practice.
The investment here is totally worth it, and I even recommend the other courses he and Academind have to offer.

results.content: This course was amazing, from the beginin till the end it got me focused and motivated. Max explains all the steps very well and the project is really well build and thought. The only thing that i think could be improved was the last part when we migrate the project we build during the course to sapper. I had no experience with server side things and had to pause and view the lectures several times for things to make sense to me. The deploying of projects to aws is not a good idea to, because many of us arent in the mood to put our credit card on a site just to try out the app we made. Maybe a solution like Netlify could work better since everyone can deploy theyr apps there for free. Other than that i'm very happy to finish this course and im going to dive into your React.js one to. thanx
